segments.text: and agreed that we would try to set a price on it and first try to sell it ourselves and then thus avoiding the having to pay the real estate fee then since we had
March, April, May, and June before moving west to begin work on July 1, then we could later hand the matter over to a real estate agent.
So when we went to sleep that night, we each agreed we were mentally and emotionally
exhausted but were hopeful for the future.
The next morning the phone awakened us at a comparatively early hour and a faculty wife real estate agent called asking about if she might sell our house.

At first, I was unwilling to allow her to consider it, but then a quick spousal conference led to the conclusion to add $10,000 to what the price we had generally concluded as an acceptable sum the previous night.
and to tell this caller that she could show the house to only one family and must do it while we were at church the following day.
Thus, Sunday afternoon at about dark, we were totally unprepared for the knock on the door when the smiling sales lady handed us a signed contract
for the house at the price we had originally asked.

Following the party, Joe and I, the reception, Joe and I went to have lunch with Ken and Ann Pierce, old friends from the young couples class, and then headed out, trying to drive as far as we could that Tuesday afternoon and evening
making our way all the miles to Fort Stockton a bit after midnight.
When we arrived in El Paso late the next afternoon, we went to the president's residence to see how well our furnishings would fit into that beautiful old structure.
Because on our previous campus visits, we had not been able to go into the house because my predecessor at UTEP had not given us access.
When we reached the structure at perhaps 4 o'clock, it seemed that almost every employee of the UTEP physical plant staff was there.
painting, papering, straightening.
So we went on to eat an early supper and came back to the president's house and with true delight wandered through that big, that commodious old structure
trying to identify with pieces of masking tape the furnishings that we wanted placed in storage, and went on and then got to our motel accommodations at about 1030, as was the habit in that era.
Of all travelers, I stopped at the desk, the motel, to see if there were any messages or phone calls to return.

My task as dean of faculty has perhaps increased a bit in its breadth and responsibility with the departure of Dr. Winerdi, Charles McCandless,
from education.
The associate dean of education came over to join us, and Chuck brought a great deal of warmth, quality, and capability to the team.
Most research matters now went to a research area.
And I became the, more than ever, the most likely recipient of every matter relating to academics, especially those in which faculty were directly involved.
These included some interesting termination
some episodes where faculty members were terminated for cause and lawsuits.
One of the
paragraph one of the more interesting matters we had to deal with soon was the visit of a federal investigating team looking at the continuing at the continuing effects of
segregation of segregation in public higher education in the south as a part of that review federal investigators spent about a week at A&M and a similar period
at Prairie View plus the same time at the University of Texas at Austin and at Texas Southern.
President Miller assigned me to coordinate with that group to try to keep him aware of what they, quote, were up to.
and to give the visitors whatever assistance they might need.
One of my first impressions was a bit of a shock when the team supposedly well-versed in higher education matters asked if the terms
put all of these in quotes, lecturer, professor, instructor, and teacher could be used interchangeably as substitutes for each other.
Late in the week after we became comparatively well acquainted,
I asked the group if there was some way that they might recommend...
I asked the group if there was a way they might recommend that engineering and agriculture at Prairie View
be moved to College Station to become part of the flagship campus, bringing faculty, students, and so forth.
My argument was that this would immediately give A&M an appropriate cadre of black faculty and students
faculty, staff, and students.
Further, I contended that the alternative was that Prairie View, by comparison, would never be able to be first class in those fields when compared to other land grant institutions.

In a few moments, the group indicated their personal agreement with the conclusions I was offering, but then just as quickly indicated that they did not believe they would be well advised to dare to offer such a proposal.
And thus, an opportunity was missed.
They did ask what I would suggest Prairie View, the Prairie View of the future might become.
And I suggested that they recommend that Prairie View be designated as the state's primary arts and science institution.

that with its because of its location not far from the urban the increasing urban sprawl northwest of houston that before many decades passed that second oldest of all texas public higher education campuses
would be located in a place that might attract a large number of Houstonians, of Houston area residents.
In my opinion, however, few of them
would be interested in agriculture and that the without real competitive quality in engineering a program in that field there would not attract Houstonians or many other
highly qualified students from Texas or elsewhere.
Nevertheless, none of the suggestions worked.
And the final result of the panel study was simply to encourage all southern states to give better additional funding to
the historically black institutions.

One of the interesting areas of effort that came my way as dean of faculties was working with the Department of Intercollegiate Athletics
having tried to play football and run track in high school and for a couple years at Austin College, I enjoyed athletic events greatly, particularly because of the spirit of A&M.
Soon after Dr. Williams arrived,
he decided not to renew the contract of Gene Stallings as head football coach.
Beebs, as he was known by everyone since his earliest years,
had played for the legendary Bear Bryant and come to A&M as the youngest head coach of a major American football program.
In one of his early, in his second or third year, he won the Southwest Conference and beat Bear and the Alabama Crimson Tide in the Cotton Bowl.
Then the program declined and Coach Stallings was unable to build a strong rapport with the faculty.
I have said to a number of individuals
As he began to, as his program, quote, began to go down the drain, most of the faculty sat on their hands and did nothing to hinder that decline, period, quote.

called upon Bud Wilkinson, who had recently retired as head coach, as the splendidly successful head coach at the University of Oklahoma, to serve as a consultant.

and brought with him a highly energetic staff.
One of the more noticeable recruiting techniques was that some of the Houston recruits were brought to College Station by helicopter, which landed at Kyle Field.
On those Saturdays, I was often asked to speak to the recruits and to welcome them to college station, a task which I very much enjoyed and from which I derived
deep personal honor.
In those sessions, I attempted to describe A&M as honestly as I knew how and to try to lay out for those young individuals the importance of their decision
About where they might go to school.
